story:
On a stormy autumn night, the sprawling Langford Estate was alive with laughter, music, and the clinking of glasses. Gregory Langford, an influential but controversial art collector, was hosting a private gala to unveil a newly acquired painting rumored to be a lost work of Caravaggio. Among the elite guests were artists, investors, and rivals, each with their own hidden reasons for being there.

As lightning flickered across the stained-glass windows of the Art Vault, Gregory was found dead — face down in his wine glass at the head of the long oak dining table. Panic ensued. The doors had been locked. No one had entered or left since dinner began.

Whispers of sabotage, jealousy, and decades-old grudges filled the marble halls. The painting itself had vanished. Gregory’s last words, scribbled in a corner of his guestbook, read only: 'The mask slips tonight.'

Four detectives — each with unique talents — have been brought in to interrogate the guests and uncover what really happened inside the Langford Estate. But with misleading alibis, staged scenes, and overlapping motives, this case may prove as layered as the stolen painting itself.

specialties.D: Investigator of financial and motive patterns

A.name: Dr. Evelyn Shaw
clues: Traces of potassium cyanide were found in the base of Gregory’s wine glass — carefully masked beneath the tannins of the red.
A partial fingerprint, smudged but consistent with pressure from a left thumb, was found on the cork of the poisoned wine bottle.
The antique dagger on display had recently been cleaned — but minute traces of blood were found under the hilt.
Residue of an uncommon cleaning solvent was detected in the Art Vault, often used to preserve canvas from UV damage.
Broken glass was embedded in the carpet near the gallery entrance — not from Gregory’s glass but from a decorative sculpture nearby.
A single red fiber was found near the chair Gregory was seated in — synthetic, not matching his or staff uniforms.
The poison used was administered recently — within 10–15 minutes of his last sip, suggesting it wasn’t planted earlier.
The Art Vault’s temperature controls had been overridden briefly at 7:43 PM — the logs were manually deleted but partially recovered.

B.name: Lt. Marcus Vane
clues: Eleanor remained unusually calm throughout the announcement of Gregory’s death, even sipping from her glass while others panicked.
Victor exhibited defensive aggression and was quick to blame ‘old ghosts’ in the room during initial questioning.
Isabelle repeatedly shifted blame to the staff — a classic projection pattern seen in public humiliation trauma.
Celeste avoided eye contact during every question about the painting — suggesting deeper emotional entanglement.
Omar flinched when the word 'audit' was mentioned, and twice misspoke Gregory's name during interviews.
Julian’s speech patterns changed drastically when discussing his withdrawn funding — indicating concealed regret or fear.
Mira’s tone fluctuated between seduction and bitterness — unresolved emotions typical of rekindled resentment.
Sebastian showed micro-expressions of satisfaction during discussions of Gregory’s death — inconsistent with mourning or fear.

C.name: Inspector Lila Grant
clues: The kitchen staff overheard Sebastian saying, 'He won’t own anything after tonight' earlier that evening.
One server noticed Mira quietly slipping away during dessert — unaccounted for for nearly 12 minutes.
Isabelle asked about security camera locations during a casual conversation, claiming she 'hated being watched'.
Julian was caught whispering to Celeste near the wine cellar shortly before the lights flickered.
Victor’s watch had been set 8 minutes fast — possibly to falsify his alibi timeline.
Omar nervously asked if the wine could be traced — before any toxicology results had been released.
A valet reported that Eleanor requested her car keys 'just in case she needed to leave fast' before dessert.
Celeste was overheard asking if Gregory’s collection was insured by name or by market value.

D.name: Agent Noah Reed
clues: Omar had discovered a forged insurance document listing a payout double the painting’s public value.
Victor stood to gain full control of Langford’s estate if Gregory died intestate — which he recently became.
Julian’s firm had pulled out after rumors Gregory was inflating valuations using false provenance.
Celeste had signed a contract to authenticate the painting publicly — then hesitated two days before the gala.
Eleanor’s gallery was bleeding money after losing the Caravaggio bid — and she owed favors to private lenders.
Isabelle’s upcoming solo exhibit was mysteriously cancelled by Gregory — tanking her reputation and income.
Sebastian had access to the vault and was bribed months ago in another gallery security breach.
Mira received a wire transfer from an anonymous offshore account two days before the gala — flagged postmortem.

Suspect 1.name: Eleanor Montgomery
Suspect 1.description: A rival gallery owner who lost a prized auction to Gregory just months ago. Known for her charisma and cutthroat deals.

A: I poured Gregory’s wine, yes. I was near the decanter. But he insisted on choosing his own bottle that night. Said it was a 'rare treat'.
I may have touched one of the glasses, but I didn’t linger. I helped adjust the seating arrangement when Gregory asked for more candles.
Now that you mention it, I did feel a chill in the Art Vault earlier — thought it was the old AC acting up again. Didn’t think it was important.
B: Would you rather I screamed? I’ve seen worse in business. People die, and I don’t fall apart. Doesn’t mean I did anything.
Gregory could be... difficult. Charismatic, yes, but he barked orders. Some staff adored him, others feared him. It depends who you ask.
Nervous? Isabelle. Always glancing around, twiddling her necklace. And Omar — sweat beading like he’d run a marathon.
C: I stepped out for air. That roast was heavy, and I needed a moment. Alone. Just the balcony and me, I swear.
Julian. We talked briefly. He was upset — muttering about 'cutting ties'. I didn’t press.
The lights flickered just after Celeste asked Gregory about the painting’s origins. Coincidence? Maybe. But the timing was eerie.
D: Gregory and I had... past dealings. He owed me favors, and I expected a return on my investments. That’s not illegal.
His death? A door closes, a window opens. But don’t twist that — I didn’t want him dead. We had more to settle.
Insurance? No, I didn’t know a thing about that. You think I needed him gone to gain something? That’s a stretch.

solution.explanation:
Omar Patel, Gregory's personal accountant, discovered a series of forged insurance documents and financial fraud tied to Gregory’s estate. He feared being implicated or silenced, and knew Gregory had invited Celeste to authenticate the painting — which would expose the fake provenance tied to the fraud.

Omar administered a fast-acting poison into Gregory’s personal wine bottle, knowing he’d select it for a toast that evening. The traces of cyanide and Omar’s suspicious behavior when asked about toxicology were key.

Though other suspects had motives — Isabelle’s humiliation, Victor’s inheritance, Celeste’s dispute — only Omar had the means, opportunity, and a calculated motive that tied into both the financial and physical evidence. The fingerprint on the cork and his panicked inquiry about chemical traces confirmed his guilt. His emotional state, while visibly shaken, masked deep fear and urgency rather than grief.
